### Only With The Signature
**QUERY ONLY** - The signature paramater allows input of a string containing alphabetically formatted properties from the request, encrypted using your developer application's private key. The server generates a hash from the properties on the backend and verifies the signature before continuing with the exchange.
#### Definition
You will need to use `?signature=` to supply your developer app's md5-encoded signature blob, and `?client=` to supply the public key. To read how to generate and format one go to the page [Security Signatures 101]() and follow the steps for your language.

*Unlike user tokens, you may only supply one developer app token in a signature... for now. ðŸ˜‰*

#### Distrobution
In order to get a developer app and the public and private key, you'll need to visit [dap.kelpstone.com (Developer App Portal)](http://dap.kelpstone.com?show=my_apps&tutorial=true), sign into your account and create an application with limited permissions. Unless you want to wait for approval, use the playground permission settings to experiment on your own account.

#### Protocol
Two conjoining query additions that you provide when making API calls. Specify the developer app's public key in a query parameter called Client and the hash in a query parameter called Signature.

Example: `?client=123&signature=202cb962ac59075b964b07152d234b70`

### Adding User-Authorized Scopes
**HEADER ONLY** - â€‹User-authorized scoped tokens which allow developer applications to edit and acess secret or protected information from or to a users profile, settings and content.

#### Definition
You can use either `Authorities` or `Authority` to optionally suply user authorized developer app scope tokens. You can include as many tokens as you need, seperated by a comma. It does not matter which header name you use, both allow for one or more items.

#### Distrobution
In order to get your developer app authorized for control over user account details, you'll need to prompt them first. Authorization methods include, prompting them to run a command ingame or redirecting them to an KelpAuth splash screen which allows them to grant the permisions. Both of which will return a token to the iniating api call's host.
